head.supplied: [February 1896 ¶ ¶ Correspondence inward ¶ ¶ 'Baron von Mueller offering to forward Economic Plants ¶ ¶ To be accepted with thanks'.]...

div.p: Minute book 11, p. 204, 12 February 1896, Borough Council records, Port Fairy, Victoria.

Transcribed 9.9.93. To proof.
name in full of Town Clerk. Letter not found. The local press provided a fuller summary of M's letter than the council: 'From Baron von Mueller, stating that as the cool season was approaching, he would be ready to send some roots of the West African Wonder grass (Panicum spectabile), which plant was introduced by him into Australia, so that a trial might be made as to whether our mild climate would be warm enough for this most valuable pasture grass. It had been proved lately that this large Panicum would succeed also on sandy sea-coasts, and along river banks, which it helped to consolidate. The Baron further intimated that he could let the council have a supply of the New Zealand flax, if they like to try that valuable fibre plant. — It was unanimously decided to accept the offer of the first mentioned plants, the council already possessing a supply of the flax.' (Port Fairy Gazette, 14 February 1896, p. 2). [February 1896
'Baron von Mueller offering to forward Economic Plants
